facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 97 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1965 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 671 of 1965.

facts.text: Punjab High Court delivered judgment and order dated December 20, 1965 in Criminal Revision No. 671 of 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 20, 1965 of the Punjab High Court in Criminal Revision No. 671 of 1965.

facts.text: Harnek Singh lodged a complaint at the Police Station, Phul, on October 15, 1964, at about 10.40 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Harnek Singh lodged a companyplaint at the Police Station, Phul, oil October 15, 1964, at about 10.40 p.m., that while companying out of a picture house, along with Surjit Singh, first respondent herein,

facts.text: Harnek Singh was coming out of a picture house along with Surjit Singh, the first respondent.

anchor.surface_text: that while companying out of a picture house, along with Surjit Singh, first respondent herein, his foot accidentally struck against a third party, Avtar Singh, who was also companying out of the picture house,

facts.text: Harnek Singh's foot accidentally struck against Avtar Singh, who was coming out with Raj Pal, the second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: his foot accidentally struck against a third party, Avtar Singh, who was also companying out of the picture house, along with Raj Pal, the second respondent.

facts.text: Avtar Singh and the second respondent picked up a quarrel with Harnek Singh but were pacified by the manager of the cinema.

anchor.surface_text: According to the companyplaint, Avtar Singh and the second respondent picked up a quarrel with Harnek Singh but they were pacified and separated by the Manner of the cinema, who intervened.

facts.text: When Harnek Singh and the first respondent were near the Civil Hospital, Phul, the second respondent fired a shot at Harnek Singh.

anchor.surface_text: It is also alleged that when later, Harnek Singh and the first respondent were near the Civil Hospital, Phul, the second respondent fired a shot at Harnek Singh.

facts.text: Police investigated the complaint and took the view that the second respondent had not participated in the occurrence and was falsely implicated on account of enmity.

anchor.surface_text: The Police appears to have invested this companyplaint and took the view that the second respondent had number participated in the occurrence and that he, has been falsely implicated on account of enmity .

facts.text: First respondent instituted a complaint before the Magistrate under sections 307, 504 and 323 read with section 34 IPC against Avtar Singh and the second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: But, before the police actually filed a companyplaint before the Magistrate against Avtar Singh alone, the first respondent instituted a companyplaint before the Magistrate under ss.307, 504 and 323 read with S.34, I.P.C., against both Avthar Singh and the second respondent.

facts.text: Magistrate held preliminary enquiry and issued summons to both accused.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate, after holding a preliminary enquiry, issued summons to both the accused.

facts.text: On January 8, 1965, Prosecuting Deputy Superintendent of Police, Bhatinda, Shri Harbans Singh, filed application under s.494 as Public Prosecutor to withdraw prosecution against second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On January 8, 1965, the Prosecuting Deputy Superintendent of Police, Bhatinda, Shri Harbans Singh, filed an application, in his capacity as Public Prosecutor, before the trial Magistrate, under s. 494 of the Code, for permission to withdraw from the prosecution of the case and for discharging the second respondent.

facts.text: Public Prosecutor stated second respondent innocent and falsely involved, fact came to knowledge during investigation.

anchor.surface_text: According to that officer, the second respondent was innocent and had been falsely involved, in the case, by the companyplainant and that this fact hid companye- to his knowledge during the investigation.

facts.text: First respondent opposed the s.494 application on grounds that officer had no locus standi as not Public Prosecutor and application not bona fide.

anchor.surface_text: The said application was opposed by the first respondent on two grounds  1  that Shri Harbans Singh, Prosecuting Deputy Superintendent of Police, did number exercise the powers of a Public Prosecutor and therefore that he had numberlocus standi to file the application and  2  that the application was number bona fide

facts.text: Trial Magistrate on February 8, 1965 overruled objections, held officer was Public Prosecutor for Bhatinda district, application bona fide, permitted withdrawal against second respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The trial Magistrate, by his order dated February 8, 1965, over ruled the objections raised by the first respondent and held that the Prosecuting Deputy Superintendent of Police was the Public Prosecutor for the entire district of Bhatinda, within whose Jurisdiction the Magistrates Court at Phul was situated, and that the application was bona fide. In companysequence, the Magistrate gave permission for the withdrawal of the case, as against the second respondent,

facts.text: First respondent challenged Magistrate's order in revision before Sessions Judge, Barnala.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the first respondent, in revision before the learned Sessions, Judge, Barnala.

facts.text: Sessions Judge held officer appointed as Public Prosecutor for Magistrates Court at Phul, could intervene in private complaint case, took charge by application, exercised jurisdiction judicially, confirmed Magistrate's order.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge held that the Officer, who filed the application under s. 494 of the Code, had been appointed as Public Prosecutor for the Magistrates Court at Phul by the Government. The Sessions Judge also held that the said 3 50 Public Prosecutor companyld intervene in a criminal case, instituted on a private companyplaint and such Public Prosecutor companyld be companysidered to be one who had taken charge of the case when he made an application to withdraw from the prosecution. ... Ultimately, the order of the trial Magistrate was companyfirmed by the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: First respondent filed revision to Punjab High Court against orders of Magistrate and Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent, again, went up in revision to the Punjab High Court, challenging the two orders passed by the trial Magistrate and the learned Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Division Bench of Punjab High Court consisting of Falshaw C.J. and Khanna J. on December 20, 1965 accepted first respondent's contentions, held Public Prosecutor cannot withdraw under s.494 from private complaint prosecution, directed complaint to proceed against both accused.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of the Punjab High Court, companysisting of Falshaw, C.J., and Khanna J., by their order dated December 20, 1965, have accepted the companytentions of the first respondent herein and have, ultimately, held that a Public Prosecutor cannot withdraw, under s. 494 of the Code, from the prosecution of a case pending before a Magistrate, instituted upon a private companyplaint, despite the companyplainants objection to the withdrawal of the case. The learned Judges, in companysequence, directed the companyplaint filed by the first respondent, against both the accused, to ,be proceeded with.

facts.text: In High Court, first respondent accepted Shri Harbans Singh vested with powers of Public Prosecutor.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court, the first respondent has accepted the position that Shri Harbans Singh, Prosecuting Deputy Superintendent of Police, Bhatinda, has been vested with powers of a Public Prosecutor, and therefore he was a Public Prosecutor.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal dismissed, upholding High Court view that Public Prosecutor not entitled to file s.494 application in private complaint case as not in charge.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Police did not file complaint against second respondent before first respondent's private complaint was instituted.

anchor.surface_text: But, before the police actually filed a companyplaint before the Magistrate against Avtar Singh alone,

facts.text: Second respondent prayed that permission for withdrawal should not be granted.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence, the second respondent prayed that permission should number be granted for withdrawal.

facts.text: High Court held Public Prosecutor has no locus standi to file s.494 in private complaint case as not in charge of prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, after a review of the decisions placed before it, has held that when a case is pending before a Magistrate and has been initiated on a police report, it is the State that numbermally arranges for the companyduct of the prosecution but, in the case of a private companyplaint before a Magistrate, which is companyducted by the companyplainant or by his duly authorized companynsel, the Public Prosecutor does number companye into the picture in the companyduct of such cases, and therefore he has numberlocus standi to file an application under s. 494 of the Code in respect of such case.

facts.text: Prosecution in the case was conducted by the first respondent as private complainant.

anchor.surface_text: In the case on hand, it is found by the High Court, that the prosecution is being companyducted by the companyplainant, viz. the first respondent herein,

issues.text: The question that arises for consideration by special leave, is regarding the right of a Public Prosecutor to file an application under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, hereinafter called the Code, in respect of a complaint filed by a private party, and which was being prosecuted by him as such.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises for companysideration by special leave, is regarding the right of a an application, under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure  hereinafter called the Code , in respect of a companyplaint, filed by a private party,

issues.text: Whether a Public Prosecutor appointed generally under s.492(1) CrPC is in charge of every prosecution conducted before the court, including private complaints, so as to be entitled to file an application under s.494 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel was also prepared to contend for the larger proposition that, even when a Public Prosecutor is appointed generally, by the Government, for any local area, under s. 492 1  of the Code, by virtue of his appointment as such Public Prosecutor, he must be considered to be in charge of every prosecution that is being conducted before that Court,

anchor.surface_text: The reasonable interpretation to be placed upon s. 494, in our opinion is that it is only the Public Prosecutor, who is incharge of a particular case and is actually conducting the prosecution,

holdings.text: A Public Prosecutor can file an application under s.494 CrPC for withdrawal from prosecution only if he is already in charge of and conducting that particular case.

anchor.surface_text: But the expression withdraw from the prosecution of any person, occurring in s. 494, in our opinion, contemplates that the Public Prosecutor, who files the application for withdrawal under that section, must be Public Prosecutor, who is already in charge of that particular case, in which the application is filed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets 'withdraw from the prosecution' in s.494 to require prior charge, read with s.493 referring to specific cases, scheme of ss.492-495, and to avoid anomalies.

holdings.text: The expression 'the Public Prosecutor' in s.494 refers only to the Public Prosecutor in charge of the particular case, not any Public Prosecutor generally appointed under s.492(1).

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept that contention of the learned counsel for the appellant that the expression the Public Prosecutor in s. 494 is to be understood as referring to any person who is a Public Prosecutor, whether he is a Public Prosecutor appointed generally, under s. 492 1  or for the purpose under of a particular case, as contemplated s. 492 2  of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects broad interpretation leading to anomalies like one PP withdrawing unrelated cases; limits to PP actually in charge per statutory scheme and s.493.

holdings.text: A Public Prosecutor does not take charge of a case merely by filing an application under s.494 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: The reasonable interpretation to be placed upon s. 494, in our opinion is that it is only the Public Prosecutor, who is incharge of a particular case and is actually conducting the prosecution,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior charge required before withdrawal; filing application presupposes existing charge, consistent with purpose of s.494 for PP who has considered materials.

holdings.text: In a private complaint case prosecuted by the complainant, the Public Prosecutor is not in charge and has no locus standi to file under s.494 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: In the case on hand, it is found by the High Court, that the prosecution is being conducted by the complainant, viz. the first respondent herein, and the Prosecuting Deputy Superintendent of Police, Bhatinda, was numberhere in the picture, when he filed the application under s. 494 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies interpretation to facts: prosecution by private party, PP not involved until permitted under s.495; High Court view correct.

holdings.text: The Bombay High Court in Ratansha Kavasji correctly held that s.494 requires the Public Prosecutor to already be in charge of the prosecution to withdraw.

anchor.surface_text: We are in entire agreement with these observations of the learned Judges of the Bombay High Court as, in our opinion, that is the correct interpretation to be placed on s. 494 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicitly approves precedent distinguishing private complaints; aligns with textual reading of 'withdraw from the prosecution'.

holdings.text: The expression 'in other cases' in s.494 means cases other than jury trials, not cases irrespective of whether PP is in charge.

anchor.surface_text: We may, at this stage, note that an argument was attempted to be raised by learned counsel for the appellant that s. 494, when it speaks of an application being filed in other cases before the judgment

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects appellant's textual argument; clarifies stage of application presupposes PP in charge.

holdings.text: Permitting any Public Prosecutor to file under s.494 without being in charge leads to anomalous results.

anchor.surface_text: If any Public Prosecutor, who had nothing to do with a particular case is held entitled to file an application under s. 494, in our opinion, the result will be very anomalous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Illustrates policy consequences like cross-withdrawals between cases or PPs.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ultimate procedural conclusion upholding High Court.

precedents.citation: The State of Bihar v. Ram Naresh Pandey 1  1957 S.C.R. 279

anchor.surface_text: the decision of this Court in The State of Bihar v. Ram Naresh Pandey 1  where, after tracing the history of the present s. 494, the Court has observed that it is right to remember that the Public Prosecutor, though an executive officer, is, in a larger sense, also an officer of the Court and that he is bound to assist the Court  1  1957 S.C.R. 279.

precedents.case_name: State of Bihar v Ram Naresh Pandey
precedents.cited_proposition: Public Prosecutor is an officer of the Court bound to assist the Court with his fairly considered view

anchor.surface_text: In Queen Empress v. Murarji Gokuldas 1 , there are numberdoubt observations to the effect that all offences affect the public and that in all prosecutions the Crown is the Public Prosecutor and that a proceeding is always treated as a proceeding between the Crown and the accused.

precedents.cited_proposition: all offences affect the public and in all prosecutions the Crown is the Public Prosecutor

precedents.citation: State v. Atmaram M. Ghosale 2  I.L.R. 1923 2 Pat. 708

anchor.surface_text: In State v. Atmaram M. Ghosale 2 , the learned Judges have observed that it is very obvious to think that all prosecutions, however initiated, are always to be deemed as prosecutions by the State.

precedents.cited_proposition: all prosecutions however initiated are always to be deemed as prosecutions by the State

precedents.citation: Gulli Bhagat v. Narain Singh 3  I.L.R. 1965 Bom. 103

anchor.surface_text: In Gulli Bhagat v. Narain Singh 3 , the learned Judges had to companysider, whether a permission granted under s. 494 of the Code, to the Public Prosecutor, to withdraw from the prosecution, can be challenged in revision, by a private party.

precedents.cited_proposition: permission under s.494 to withdraw cannot be challenged by private party; Crown is prosecutor

precedents.citation: Amar Narain v. State of Rajasthan 4  A.I.R. 1952 Raj. 42

anchor.surface_text: In Amar Narain v. State of Rajasthan 4 , the learned Judges had occasion to deal with a matter similar to the one that came up before the Patna High Court in Gulli Bhagats CaSe 3 .

precedents.case_name: Amar Narain v State of Rajasthan
precedents.cited_proposition: private party has no right to challenge withdrawal order by Public Prosecutor in revision

precedents.citation: Sher Singh v. Jitendranath 1  A.I.R. 1931 Cal. 607

anchor.surface_text: In Sher Singh v. Jitendranath 1 , the learned Judges had occasion to companysider the question as to the legality of an application for withdrawal of prosecution filed by a Public Prosecutor, entering appearance for that purpose only.

precedents.cited_proposition: Public Prosecutor entering appearance only for withdrawal is not illegal

precedents.cited_proposition: Public Prosecutor can file withdrawal application in private complaint case if he has taken charge

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Nuruddin Ahmed, learned companynsel for the first respon- dent, has referred us to the observations of the Bombay High Court in Ratansha Kavasji v. Behramsha Pardiuala 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Public Prosecutor can withdraw under s.494 only if already in charge of the prosecution
precedents.cited_holding: unless the Public Prosecutor is already in charge of the prosecution, he cannot withdraw from it

precedents.citation: Queen Empress v. Murariji Gokuldas 1888 13 Bom. 389

anchor.surface_text: The remarks that Mr. Thakor has relied on in Queen Empress v. Murariji Gokuldas 1888 13 Bom. 389 appear to have been made with reference to cases in which the prosecution is companyducted by the Public Prosecutor.

anchor.surface_text: But the expression withdraw from the prosecution of any person, occurring in s. 494, in our opinion, contemplates that the Public Prosecutor, who files the application for withdrawal under that section, must be Public Prosecutor, who is already in charge of that particular case, in which the application is filed.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: We are not inclined to accept that contention of the learned counsel for the appellant that the expression the Public Prosecutor in s. 494 is to be understood as referring to any person who is a Public Prosecutor, whether he is a Public Prosecutor appointed generally, under s. 492 1  or for the purpose under of a particular case, as contemplated s. 492 2  of the Code.
The appeal therefore fails and is dismissed.
